title: This is how much Americans now need to enter the top 1pc
text:
One definition of rich is getting into the top 1 per cent. If that's your goal, it's becoming harder to reach.

The income needed to exit the bottom 99 per cent of US taxpayers hit $US515,371 ($752,190) in 2017, according to Internal Revenue Service data released last week. That's up 7.2 per cent from a year earlier, even after adjusting for inflation.

To join the top 0.1 per cent, you would have needed to earn $US2.4 million in 2017. Phil Carrick

Since 2011, when Occupy Wall Street protesters rallied under the slogan "We are the 99 per cent", the income threshold for the top 1 per cent is up an inflation-adjusted 33 per cent. That outpaces all other groups except for those that are even wealthier.

To join the top 0.1 per cent, you would have needed to earn $US2.4 million in 2017, an increase of 38 per cent since 2011. The top 0.01 per cent threshold has jumped 46 per cent.

Meanwhile, the top 0.001 per cent - an elite group of 1433 taxpayers - earned at least $US63.4 million each in 2017, up 51 per cent since the Occupy protests.
